metadata.title: Removal of humic acid from aqueous solution using UV/ZnO nano-photocatalysis and adsorption

sections.text:
Journal of Molecular Liquids xxx (2015) xxx–xxx
MOLLIQ-05008; No of Pages 7
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Molecular Liquids
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /mol l iq
Removal of humic acid from aqueous solution using UV/ZnO nano-photocatalysis and adsorption
V. Oskoei a, M.H. Dehghani a,b,⁎, S. Nazmara a, B. Heibati a,c, M. Asif d, I. Tyagi e, Shilpi Agarwal e, Vinod Kumar Gupta e,f,g,⁎⁎ a Department of Environmental Health Engineering, School of Public Health, Tehran University, Iran b Institute for Environmental Research, Center for Solid Waste Research, Tehran, Iran c Health Sciences Research Centre, Department of Occupational Health Engineering, Faculty of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran Health, Mazandaran University of Medical Sciences, Sari, Iran d Department of Chemical Engineering, King Saud University Riyadh, Saudi Arabia e Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee 247667, India f Center for Environment and Water, The research Institute, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals, Dhahran 31261, Saudi Arabia g Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Johannesburg, Johannesburg, South Africa
⁎ Correspondence to: M.H. Dehghani, Departmen Engineering, School of Public Health, Tehran University, Ir ⁎⁎ Correspondence to: V.K. Gupta, Department of C Technology Roorkee 247667, India.
E-mail addresses: vinodfcy@iitr.ac.in, vinodfcy@gmail.
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2015.07.052 0167-7322/© 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Please cite this article as: V. Oskoei, et al., Rem Liq. (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.moll
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 7 June 2015 Received in revised form 17 July 2015 Accepted 20 July 2015 Available online xxxx
Keywords: Humic acid Natural organic material Zinc oxide nanoparticles Photocatalysis Optimization
Humic acid is a natural organicmaterial produced as a result of biological and geochemical reactions and it is one of themain precursormaterials of disinfection by-products. The rapid removal and fast adsorption of humic acid using zinc oxide nanoparticle irradiated by the ultraviolet light (ZnO/UV) were well elucidated and investigated. The impact of various influential factors such as ZnO dosage, initial humic acid concentration, reaction time and pH on the adsorption capacity and removal of humic acid was well studied and optimized. The optimization study confirms that an increase in the initial concentration of humic acid and the pH of the environment decreased the removal efficiency while increase in the time of irradiation increased the removal efficiency. The maximum removal efficiency of humic acid for the single-stage process was found to be 0.2 g/l ZnO and for that of two-stage process was found to be 0.5 g/l ZnO. The obtained results reveal that the two-stage photocatalysis was the most preferable method for the humic acid removal and it results in more than 98.95% of humic acid within only 30 min of photocatalysis.
© 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Natural organic matter (NOM) is an organic compound originating from the biological and synthetic sources that are one of the major impurities which are present in all the nearby aqueous sources. These compounds are different in their chemical reactivity, structure and color [1,2]. The major components of NOM include carbohydrates, protein, and lignin; a significant percentage of their molecular weight comprised of decomposed oxygen-containing functional groups. Hydrophilic NOM has a higher potential for formation of halo acetic acid in comparison to that of the hydrophobic NOM [3]. The presence of NOM affects the water quality and is a major problematic issue for municipal wastewater treatment plants. In the past, the existence of humic acid in potable water was undesirable primarily for its lack
t of Environmental Health an. hemistry, Indian Institute of
com (V.K. Gupta).
oval of humic acid fromaque iq.2015.07.052
of esthetic appeal (color). It is now known to be undesirable for its disinfection by-products, such as THMs, which are often carcinogenic. Although NOM is harmless by itself, it produces adverse reactions with chlorine and forms disinfection by-products [4].
Evaluation of NOM in untreatedwastewater consists of the potential carcinogenic trihalomethane (THM) compounds which have severe detrimental effect on the human health. The decline in potable water resources and rise of noxious impurities in water require a tremendous effort of the research groups for purification and strict disinfection laws for the control of THM and haloacetic acids, which occur in amounts of about 80 μg/l and 60 μg/l, respectively, in water. It illustrates the need for new technologies for water treatment. One new method for the removal of disinfection by-product (DBP) precursors is advanced oxidation [4,5]. The major advantage of this method is organic carbon mineralization [6]. This process is based on the formation of highly reactive species of hydroxyl radicals that can remove a wide range of contamination [7]. Photocatalysis has been successfully used for the oxidation of many organic pollutants by advanced oxidation. Heterogeneous photocatalysis disrupts the mineralization of most organic compounds [8–17]. Heterogeneous metal oxides such as ZnO have the potential to remove organic substances from aquatic environments in
ous solution usingUV/ZnOnano-photocatalysis and adsorption, J.Mol.
the presence of ultraviolet light. The main advantage of ZnO is that it absorbs a range of electromagnetic waves and shows high performance as a decomposition photocatalyst of organic compounds in aqueous solutions [18–49].
The present study evaluated the performance of a nano-photocatalytic reactor (UV/ZnO) for removal of humic acid from aqueous solutions. ZnO nanoparticleswere used as catalysts for the removal of humic acid. The effects of pH, concentration of humic acid, concentration of nanoparticles, processing time, and absorption were examined and synthetic studies were carried out.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text:
The experimental study was carried out using a batch system and the natural organic material humic acid was obtained from Acros Organics. Furthermaterials usedwere obtained fromMerck (Germany).
A stock solution of 1 g/l humic acid was prepared using humic acid that contained impurities. It was purified according to the method reported by Zaccone et al. (2007). According to this method, we first measure out 1.82 g of 57% purified humic acid [50], which was further treated with 0.2 M KOH and then 0.3 M KOH solution and stirred for 4–5 h. It was then centrifuged to remove the insoluble substances such as organic litter. The pH of the supernatant was acidified using HCl to pH=1.5 and the coagulated parts were separated by centrifugation. The purified humic acid was washed with distilled water and HCL (pH = 3), then centrifuged.
The sedimentation volumewas increased to 1000mg/lwith distilled water and the solution was added and shaken for 3 h. The final product was a hypotonic solution with a concentration of 1 g/l. The blank stock solution was kept at 4 °C. The concentration of humic acid remaining in the samples was determined by spectroscopically using PerkinElmer Lambda 25 UV/vis; CT, USA with a calibration curve drawn at 254 nm [51].
The reactor consists of a cylinder of volume of 3 l. A magnetic stirrer inside the cylinder thoroughly mixed the samples under UV irradiation. To adjust the light from UV irradiation, a sample was cooled on ice. The temperature was monitored using a thermometer and kept constant. UV radiation was supplied by a medium pressure mercury lamp at 125W (Arda, France). The lamp was placed inside a transparent quartz coverwith a diameter of 3 cm. Nanoparticles of ZnOwere obtained from Nanopars Spadana Company. Table 1 lists the properties of the obtained nanoparticles. The surface textural and morphological properties i.e. SEM and TEM microphotograph of ZnO nanoparticle were presented in Fig. 1.
ZnO/UV processing was carried at initial humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/l at contact times of 1, 3, 5, 10, 20, 30, 45 and 60 min, different pH values (4, 7, 10) and two concentrations of nanoparticles (0.2 and 0.5 g/l). The processing was performed in one and two stages. The single-stage samples were 250 ml with ZnO added at
Table 1 ZnO nanoparticle specifications.a.
Product name ZnO nanoparticle
Chemical formula ZnO Purity 99.8% Grain size 6–12 nm Specific surface 40–150 m2/g Appearance Light spongy mass Color White Shape particle Orb (sphere) Density 105 kg/m2 Crystal structure Hexagonal Phase form ZnO
a Nanoparticles of ZnO were obtained from Nanopars Spadana Company (Isfahan, I.R., Iran).
Please cite this article as: V. Oskoei, et al., Removal of humic acid fromaque Liq. (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2015.07.052
the desired concentrations. The samples were stirred under UV irradiation using amagnetic stirrer. The samples were periodically sampled by extracting out 10ml, which created a perceptible change in the volume of the synthetic solution.
Because these nanoparticles can spontaneously deposit, the sample was kept motionless for 30 min so that the majority of particles settled to the bottom. The samples were then centrifuged for 10 min (HettichUniversal) at a speed of 6000 rpm so that the remaining particles were deposited. After centrifuging, turbid sampleswerefiltered through a filter with a pore size of 0.45 μn using a vacuum pump. The concentration of humic acid remaining was then measured by spectrophotometer. The two-stage phases were carried out in a similar manner.
This step determined the optimal conditions for the nanophotocatalytic operating system. It tested the levels and ranges of the variables to get optimum results from the nanophotocatalytic reactor. A synthetic study of the nanophotocatalytic process was also carried out to obtain optimum conditions.
Ethic statement
a. No specific permits were required for the described field studies. b. No specific permissions were required for these locations/activities. c. Location is not privately-owned or protected in any way. d. The field studies did not involve endangered or protected species.
ous solution usingUV/ZnOnano-photocatalysis and adsorption, J.Mol.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of pH on single-stage nanophotocatalysis
sections.text:
Three levels of pH (4, 7, 10)were tested to examine the impact of pH on humic acid removal at intervals of 1 to 60min, humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/l and two ZnO nanoparticle concentrations. Fig. 2 shows that single-stage UV/ZnO nano-photocatalysis in acidic pH (4) removed 97.47%, 87.76%, 76.69% and 69.29% of the humic acid, respectively. For alkaline pH (10), the results were 82.56%, 76.02%, 70.18% and 52.29%, respectively. At neutral pH (7), the humic acid removal rates were 90.95%, 76.02%, 70.18% and 61.79%. Hence the obtained results clearly indicate that acidic pH produced better results than neutral pH and neutral pH produced better results than alkaline pH.
The increased removal of humic acid at acidic pH (4) is in response to the presence of acidic ions of H+ (hydrogen) that increased formation of •H radicals, it can be generated in three ways: (1) when cavities react with water molecules in pairs of electron-holes to form •OH and •H; (2) when •OH attacks the aromatic ring and breaks apart the bonded carbon-hydrogen so that hydrogen forms •OH and •H; UV light is required to supply the energy to break the covalent bonds; (3) when H and •H form HO2 radicals using the oxygen present in solution to eventually form •OH radicals [52].
The degradation of humic acid increased in the presence of other •OH radicals that formed during photocatalysis. The good performance of anionic humic acid degradation in an acidic environment by ZnO nanoparticles contributed to the positive charge. There is no evidence for positive charges in ZnO, but documentary evidence points to a positive charge in an acidic environment. It can be concluded that the dominant charge of ZnO is positive in an acidic environment which then absorbs humic acid anions electrostatically. This means that the most efficient removal of humic acid occurred at pH = 4 [52–54].

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of absorbent dose on single-stage nanophotocatalysis
sections.text:
To examine the effect of ZnO nanoparticle dose on UV/ZnO singlestage performance, ZnO was tested at 0.2 and 0.5 g/l, at intervals of 1 to 60 min, pH values of 4, 7 and 10 and humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/l. This study showed that increasing the ZnO concentration from 0.2 to 0.5 g/l decreased removal of humic acid from 97.47%, 87.76%, 78.33% and 69.29% to 84.02%, 74.16%, 68.91% and 65.02%, respectively. Hence increasing the dosage of catalyst substrate in a solution increased thenumber of active sites on the catalyst andUV trapping increased. This increased the speed of restoration of anionic humic acid and, ultimately, light absorption [53]. The higher dose of nanoparticles as a source of light photons had a negative effect on the removal rate and adsorption. The increase in light scattering from the nanoparticles,
Please cite this article as: V. Oskoei, et al., Removal of humic acid fromaque Liq. (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2015.07.052
agglomeration and accumulation of nanoparticles are some of the other reasons for decreased efficiency [52,53,55–57]. This experiment established 0.2 g ZnO as optimal level for testing.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of contact time on single-stage nanophotocatalysis
sections.text:
The effect of contact time on UV/ZnO single-stage performance was tested at intervals of 1 to 60min, pH levels of 4, 7 and 10 and humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/l. Fig. 3 showed that increasing the contact time from 3 min to 10 min increased removal efficiency. After 30 min, removal efficiency remained nearly constant.
The removal efficiencywas rapid at the beginning because therewere a large number of active sites available on the surface of the adsorbent. The number of sites decreased over time with the gradual occupation of sites by humic acid, which the result in the increase of repulsive forces between the adsorbed molecules, it leads to decreased removal or adsorption of humic acid. In addition, increasing the contact time between the UV light and ZnO increased the number of pairs of electron-holes released. As exposure time increased, more electrons were generated, which increased the removal rate (Eq. (1)) [58,59].
ZnOþ hv→ZnO hþ þ e− ð1Þ

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of initial humic acid concentration on single-stage nanophotocatalysis
sections.text:
The effect of the initial concentration of humic acid on single-stage UV/ZnO performance was tested at intervals of 1 to 60 min, humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/L, pH of 4, 7 and 10 and two levels of ZnOnanoparticles. This study showed that increasing the initial concentration of humic acid decreased the removal efficiency. The efficiency of humic acid removal at the listed concentrations at optimum pH (4) and catalyst (0.2 g) was 97.47%, 87.76%, 78.33% and 69.29%, respectively. When the humic acid concentration increased from 5 mg/l to 10 mg/l, the removal efficiency of 0.2 g sorbent decreased from 76.87% to 29.69%. For 0.5 g sorbent, as the initial concentration of humic acid increased from 5 mg/l to 10 mg/l, removal efficiency increased from16.74% to 20.65%. The reason for the decreasewith an increase in initial concentration is that lower levels of humic acid provide more absorption surfaces; these levels decreased as the concentration increases and repulsive forces between molecules occurred [60].
The concentrations of generated radicals in all solutions were the same, so a solution with a low concentration of humic acid with the same amount of hydroxyl radicals will have a higher degradation rate than a solution with a high concentration [60]. Fryxell and Cao (2007) studied humic acid adsorption on polyaniline and found that
ous solution usingUV/ZnOnano-photocatalysis and adsorption, J.Mol.
the absorption efficiency decreased as the humic acid concentration increased, but the amount of humic acid adsorbed per mass unit of adsorbent increased. The concentration of humic acid increased from 10 mg/l to 40 mg/l, removal efficiency decreased and the amount of humic acid adsorbed per mass unit of adsorbent increased from 15 to 40 [60].

sections.heading: 3.5. Effect of absorbent dose on two-stage process: (A) ZnO; (B) UV
sections.text:
The effect of ZnO nanoparticle dose on two-stage UV/ZnO performance was tested at doses of 0.2 and 0.5 g/l nanoparticles, pH of 4,7 and 10 and humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10mg/l. The results revealed that the removal of humic acid increased as the absorbent concentration increased. On other hand, at a 2 mg/l humic acid concentration, increasing the absorbent from 0.2 g to 0.5 g increased removal of humic acid from 90.98% to 98.95%. The reason is that the increase in concentration increased the availability of absorbent surfaces for uptake.
The removal efficiency increased as the amount of absorbent increased, but the absorption capacity (amount absorbed per mass unit of adsorbent) decreased. The decrease in the absorption capacity can be attributed to intraparticle reactions caused by increased absorption density, which decreased the absorbent area and increased unsaturated sites [61,62]. They studied humic acid removal using natural unmodified zeolite and obtained similar results. They found out that the removal efficiency increased from 30% to 80% as the absorbent dosage increased from 2 g/l to 10 g/l. They postulated that van derWaals attraction forces and electrostatic attraction forces between molecules of natural zeolite and humic acid increased the removal efficiency [61].

sections.heading: 3.6. Effect of contact time on two-stage UV/ZnO: (A) ZnO; (B) UV
sections.text: To test the effect of contact time on two-stage UV/ZnO, testing was done at intervals of 1 to 30 min of humic acid removal, pH of 4, 7 and 10 and initial humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/l. Fig. 4 shows that increase in exposure time from 3 to 5 min and from 5 to 10 min increased the removal efficiency, but that removal rate became constant nearly after 10 min. More humic acid was removed at the beginning as the longer contact of the sorbent with the dissolved humic acid filled the large number of vacancies on the surface of the adsorbent. As the number of sites decreased over time, the gradual occupation of the sites decreased as the repulsive forces between absorbed molecules increased [60].

sections.heading: 3.6.1. Comparison of single-stage and two-stage UV/ZnO
sections.text:
Fig. 5 shows that during the two-stage nano-photocatalysis when ZnO dosages increased from 0.2 to 0.5 g/l, the humic acid removal
Please cite this article as: V. Oskoei, et al., Removal of humic acid fromaque Liq. (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2015.07.052
efficiency increased from 87.4% to 94.6%. For single-stage UV/ZnO nano-photocatalysis, when the adsorbent dosage increased from 0.2 to 0.5 g/l, removal efficiency of humic acid decreased from 69.29% to 65.02%. This indicates that as the nanoparticles increased, the process was influenced by light penetration, which had a negative effect on the light photon source. Advanced oxidation, which contributes to the effect of UV radiation, is not successful in highly turbid or colored water. Increase in light scattering from thenanoparticles, agglomeration and accumulation of nanoparticles are other reasons for decreased efficiency [53,53,56,57]. In the process carried out in two discrete steps, interference by turbidity disappeared with the increase in concentration, which increased the adsorbent surface and uptake. The results showed that the removal efficiency increased as the adsorbent increased, but absorption capacity decreased. The reason for this is that internal particle reactions, such as the density of the absorptive surface area, increased, it increased the unsaturated sites on the adsorbent surface [61–63].
Hartono et al. [64] studied humic acid removal fromaqueous solutions using graphite oxide. They found that increase in the absorbent dosage initially increased removal to a certain degree, but it later decreased. This was the result of decreased levels of absorbent, condensation and more unsaturated empty sites. In the two-stage process, increasing exposure time increased humic acid removal efficiency because turbidity disappeared in a short time [64].

sections.heading: 3.7. Humic acid removal using ZnO nanoparticles
sections.text:
In order to determine the decrease in the rate of humic acid using ZnO nanoparticles, experiment was carried out at optimized pH (4), humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/l at ZnO nanoparticle
ous solution usingUV/ZnOnano-photocatalysis and adsorption, J.Mol.
concentrations of 0.2 and 0.5 g/l. The study showed that the maximum removal of humic acid at 0.5 g/l after 45min. Also, this study showed the decrease in humic acid was 21% to 41% and efficiency increased as the nanoparticle concentration increased and the humic acid decreased.

sections.heading: 3.7.1. Humic acid removal by UV irradiation (photolysis)
sections.text:
To determine the decrease in humic acid from photolysis, tests were carried out at the optimal pH (4) at initial humic acid concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/l. Fig. 6 shows that photolysis required more time to remove humic acid than compilation. Increasing the contact time from 1 to 30 min and from 30 to 50 min increased removal efficiency; after 50min, the rate became nearly constant. The highest removal efficiency was at 50min aftermixing. This occurred because increasing the contact time increased the hydroxyl radicals produced by UV radiation, which increased the oxidation rate [65,66]. Humic acid removal was 73.42% to 81.4% for photolysis, which shows the high efficiency of this process.
The humic acid concentration decreased as the exposure time increased and efficiency declined. The decrease in efficiency may have occurred in response to the competition for reactions with hydroxyl at high concentrations.

sections.heading: 3.8. Adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
An adsorption isothermwas used to describe the reaction of a material with a sorbent and optimize the amount of adsorbent [67]. Isotherm modeling using nano-ZnO at 2 and 0.5 mg/l humic acid and pH 4 was investigated using the Langmuir and Freundlich models.
The Langmuir equation is expressed as [68,69]:
ce q ¼ 1 qekL þ ce qe
ð2Þ
where:
Ce soluble material concentration in counterpoise (mg/l) qe adsorption capacity in counterpoise (mg/g) q adsorption rate (mg/g) KL Langmuir equation constant
The Freundlich equation is expressed as [68,69]:
logqe ¼ logkf þ 1 n logCe ð3Þ
where:
qe maximum adsorption capacity (mg/g) Ce adsorb ion equilibrium concentration (mg/l) Kf and n Freundlich equation constants
Table 3 Comparison of adsorption capacity of other adsorbents with adsorbent in present study.
Adsorbent qmax (mg/g) References
Chitosan 28 [61] ChitinFly ash 27 [61] Fly ash 36 [62] Fly ash 10 [62] ZnO 0.82 This study's
Please cite this article as: V. Oskoei, et al., Removal of humic acid fromaque Liq. (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2015.07.052
The Langmuir isotherm showed physical adsorption of humic acid molecules by adsorbent. Adsorbent particles were placed in a layer of molecules on the surface of the absorbent. The results showed that the Langmuir isotherm correlated most strongly in this study (R2 N 0.99). The Freundlich model also correlated with the experimental data (R2 N 0.97). The Langmuir equation obtained the maximum adsorption capacity (qmax) of ZnO nanoparticles at 0.82 mg/g for relatively low uptake by the adsorbent (Table 2).
A comparison of the maximum adsorption capacity of other adsorbents and the absorbent used in this study is listed in Table 3. Hartono et al. [64] studied the removal of humic acid from aqueous solutions using graphite and graphite oxide. Their results showed that absorption wasmore similar to that in the Langmuir isotherm than the Freundlich. Zhang et al. [70] studied the removal of humic acid from aqueous solution using chitosan granules and obtained similar results; the highest intake of this absorbent was 0.41 mg/g, which seems low.

sections.heading: 3.8.1. Synthetic humic acid reaction
sections.text:
A synthetic humic acid reaction was also examined. This reaction obeyed first-order kinetics:
Ln C ¼ −K t þ Ln C0 ð4Þ
The photo catalytic reaction rate constant is k, C0 is the initial concentration of humic acid (mg/l), C is the concentration of humic acid after irradiation for time t (mg/l) and t is the irradiation time (minutes). A comparison shows that the reaction rate was constant (Fig. 7 and Table 4).
When pH and initial humic acid concentration increased, reaction speed decreased. This means that increase in the concentration of the reaction decreased by a power of 1.
The kinetic reaction of humic acid removal was investigated for compilation under optimum conditions. Table 5 shows the results of the kinetics of humic acid under continuous UV/ZnO for a second-order synthetic reaction. Fig. 8 indicates that the reaction rate was constant; as pH and initial humic acid concentration increased, reaction speed

ous solution usingUV/ZnOnano-photocatalysis and adsorption, J.Mol.

sections.heading: 3.8.2. Synthetic adsorption reaction for separate process
sections.text:
Changes in composition and concentration affect reactor water purification. Changes occur during hydraulic transmission of materials into and out of a reactor and when the reaction takes place. The rate of change and the changes that occur must be defined to completely describe a reactor. Reaction kinetics was used to study adsorption kinetics to predict the absorption rate for design and modeling.
The present study examined the kinetics of pseudo-first-order and second-order equations (Eq. (6)) as a pseudo-first-order kinetic [71–73]. This kinetic was used to describe the adsorption rate for absorption capacity. This parameter plays no special role in the adsorption process [74].
log 1− qt qe ¼ − k1 2:303 t ð6Þ
qt humic acid adsorption amount at time t (mg/l) qe nanoparticle adsorption capacity in equilibrium state (mg/l) k1 first-order same rate constant (min−1)
Eq. (7) is expressed as pseudo-second-order kinetics:
t qt ¼ 1 k2qe2 þ t qe
ð7Þ
Here, k2 is the second-order same rate constant (g/mg−1 min−1). Second-order kinetics was used to calculate the primary adsorption rate (h) in Eq. (8):
h ¼ k2q2e ð8Þ
Please cite this article as: V. Oskoei, et al., Removal of humic acid fromaque Liq. (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2015.07.052
Table 6 indicates that pseudo-second-order kinetics correlated well with the results of this study (R2 = 0.9998). The pseudo-second-order model assumed that adsorption can control absorption and that the occupancy rate of absorption is proportional to the square of the number of unoccupied sites [66–78]. The kinetic curves are shown in Figs. 9 and 10. The k2 value for concentrations of 2, 5, 7 and 10 mg/l of humic acid were 0.02, 0.06, 0.11 and 0.19 mg/g/min.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Rapid removal of humic acid from wastewater using UV/ZnO nanophotocatalysis waswell elucidated and investigated. The obtained results indicate that the removal efficiency of humic acid using the single-stage process and the two-stage process was affected by several influential parameters like exposure time, acidity and the initial concentration of humic acid. Removal occurs continuously over time, but removal efficiency was higher at the beginning of the exposure. The efficiency of
ous solution usingUV/ZnOnano-photocatalysis and adsorption, J.Mol.
this process was found higher under acidic conditions. Single-stage removal efficiency decreased as the nanoparticle concentration increased. In the two-stage process, there was a direct relationship between the increase in efficiency and nanoparticle concentration. The results show that photocatalysis using ZnO nanoparticles under UV irradiation effectively decreased humic acid to 2 from 10 ppm within 30 to 60 min. This is a very effective technology for removal of humic and other organic substances from an aquatic environment.
